text:
"Franklin Square, in 1856" p.37

Pelletreau, William S.
Early New York houses with historical - genealogical notes.
New York: Francis P. Harper, 1900.
title: Manhattan: Franklin Square.

text:
17 Cherry Street, south side, east of Dover Street.
About 1923.
Gift of E. M. Jenks.

ASSUMING STREET TO
BE EAST AND WEST

(1) Cherry Street, north side, east of Franklin Square, as seen from under the Brooklyn Bridge. May 3, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, slightly eastward.

September 7, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(1) Cherry Street, north side, east of Franklin Square, as seen from under the Brooklyn Bridge. May 3, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, slightly eastward.

September 7, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

Cherry Street, south side, from east of Dover Street, to and including Roosevelt Street.
September 9, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

Dover Street, east from but not including Franklin Square.
September 7, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

Frankfort Street, west from, but not including Pearl Street. Brooklyn Bridge under-structure shown on the right.

September 7, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

Dover Street, at Pearl Street. The view shows the Franklin Square Station of the Second and Third Aves., Elevated, directly under the Manhattan Approach to the Brooklyn Bridge. The tower of the Municipal Building, is seen in the distant background.

March 27, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

15-27 Cherry Street, south side, east of Dover Street. The Brooklyn Bridge cuts through this street, making it impossible for any houses to be built from Dover Street to the vacant lot at the right of this picture, which would probably be No. 13 Cherry Street.

1932.

J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.

(1)

Showing the clearance mentioned afore.

May 3, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

17, 19 and 21 Cherry Street. These three buildings being frame houses, two of which have a brick front. Note the demolition of buildings that formerly stood at No. 23 and eastward.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)

November 19, 1936.

15-27 Cherry Street, south side, east of Dover Street. The Brooklyn Bridge cuts through this street, making it impossible for any houses to be built from Dover Street to the vacant lot at the right of this picture, which would probably be No. 13 Cherry Street.

1932.

J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.

(1)

Showing the clearance mentioned afore.

May 3, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

17, 19 and 21 Cherry Street. These three buildings being frame houses, two of which have a brick front. Note the demolition of buildings that formerly stood at No. 23 and eastward.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)

November 19, 1936.

26 Cherry Street (rear building) north side, between Dover and Roosevelt Street's. This view is taken from inside of hallway of street building and under a wooden passageway connecting the two structures. See other views for details.

May 3, 1932

P. L. Sperr

Pearl Street, west side, south from Dover Street, and showing the Franklin Square Station of the Second and Third Aves., Elevated. Steel beams silhouetted across the top, are part of the Brooklyn Bridge Approach.  Buildings observed in the distance, are the City Service and Bank of Manhattan.
June 24, 1933.
P.L. Sperr.

(1)
Cherry Hill section in the neighborhood of Franklin Square during the Feast of St. Rocco, showing banners being carried by children.
August 16, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
Children carrying shrine of St. Rocco during festival up Cherry Hill section about the Franklin Square neighborhood.
August 16, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
Louis Russo and Son at the Feast of St. Rocco on Cherry Hill in the Franklin Square neighborhood.
August 16, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

(1) 26 Cherry Street, (rear building) north side, between Dover and Roosevelt streets. Deep shadow on the right, is caused by a covered passageway connecting both front and rear buildings.

March 20, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) A view from the adjoining yard (No. 28), and showing the afore mentioned passageway.

March 20, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

(3) A view of the eastern side of the same rear building, as seen from the same point of view as No. 2. Also shown is the debris littered back yard of No. 28.

March 20, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

March 20, 1936.

P. L. SPERR.
